reject.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to refuse to accept, believe in, or agree with something
reject.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Sarah rejected her brother’s offer of help.
Dexter flatly rejected (=completely rejected) calls for his resignation.
His proposal was rejected outright (=completely rejected).
reject.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to not choose someone for a job, course of study etc
reject.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: It’s obvious why his application was rejected.
reject.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to throw away something that has just been made, because its quality is not good enough
reject.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: If inspectors find a defective can, the batch is rejected.
reject.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to refuse to give someone any love or attention
reject.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Children feel abandoned or rejected if they don’t see their parents regularly.
reject.translation[0].definitions[4].def: if your body rejects an organ, after a transplant operation, it does not accept that organ
reject.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: He has not rejected the idea outright.
The British proposals were firmly rejected by the other EU countries.
He flatly rejected the rebel’s demands.
My client totally rejects the accusations.
The board unanimously rejected the proposal.
On May 21, the House decisively rejected the president’s proposed budget.
reject.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a product that has been rejected because there is something wrong with it
reject.translation[1].definitions[1].def: someone who is not accepted or liked by another person, or by other people
reject.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: They felt that they were society’s rejects.
reject.translation[2].definitions[0].def: to refuse to accept a request, suggestion, or offer
reject.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: The Commerce Departmentrejected applications for 39 export licenses.
Theproposals wererejected by a large majority.
reject.translation[2].definitions[1].def: to refuse to accept someone for a job, course of study etc
reject.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: He was rejected for the job because of his age.
reject.translation[2].definitions[2].def: to throw away or refuse to accept something that has been made because its quality is not good enough
reject.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: A buyer may reject goods which do not conform to the sample.
reject.translation[3].definitions[0].def: a product which is not good enough and will be thrown away or sold cheaply
